item.title: Should you turn off Crossplay in EA FC 24?
item.content:encoded:
https://www.destructoid.com/should-you-turn-off-crossplay-in-ea-fc-24/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=should-you-turn-off-crossplay-in-ea-fc-24

Crossplay is indeed a double-edged sword when it comes to the general gameplay of EA FC 24. Matchmaking queues may go faster with the feature on, but veteran players may advise you to turn the feature off.

The feature was introduced for the first time in FIFA 23 after periods of limited testing among players. Thanks to crossplay, players could play against each other without any platform restrictions (as long as they belong to the same generation of consoles). While enabling it definitely helps in matchmaking, there are a few cons, too.

Should you disable crossplay in EA FC 24?

We suggest keeping crossplay on to expedite your queues in EA FC 24. However, if you’re having problems with matchmaking, you may want to consider toggling it off to see if adjusting the option helps.

While I did opt to keep crossplay on when EA FC 24 was released, matchmaking has been smoother since I turned it off. Even when the pings are the same, matchmaking between two players on the same platform seems to be a lot smoother. My players on the pitch are far more responsive, and network fluctuations appear to be almost non-existent.

If you have a really smooth internet and don’t like to wait long for matchmaking, you can enable crossplay. As I said, the fluctuations are rare (unless the servers are experiencing severe issues), and your better internet might avoid the problems in my case.

Disabling crossplay in EA FC 24 is pretty straightforward – just go to Matchmaking from in-game settings, where you can disable it. Do note that this feature is always enabled by default, so you need to turn it off at least once manually.

What are the advantages of crossplay in EA FC 24?

The most significant benefit comes from faster matchmaking as the available pool of players grows. Earlier, in games like FIFA 22, Xbox players could only play with other users on the same platform, and the same applied to PC and PlayStation. Once crossplay was enabled, the pool suddenly merged all these three player bases.

Naturally, quicker matchmaking has many benefits. With crossplay, players can easily play with their friends in co-op sessions without having to worry about their platforms. This was not possible a couple of years back without the presence of crossplay.

What are the disadvantages of crossplay in EA FC 24?

While crossplay allows you to play without any restrictions on your platform, there are certain issues with matchmaking. Several users have reported occasional data fluctuations within matches, especially when server loads are heavy.

While such fluctuations don’t always occur, they can be problematic, especially if you’re playing competitive modes like Division Rivals and Champions Finals. That momentary drop in your connection could result in conceding goals and leading to losses.

item.title: Survival crafting game Dig or Die heads to consoles nearly 10 years after Early Access debut
item.content:encoded:
https://www.destructoid.com/survival-crafting-game-dig-or-die-heads-to-consoles-nearly-10-years-after-early-access-debut/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=survival-crafting-game-dig-or-die-heads-to-consoles-nearly-10-years-after-early-access-debut

Gaddy Games first brought the survival crafting action of Dig or Die to Steam Early Access back in March 2015, followed by the full launch in July 2018. Now, nearly a decade after its initial Early Access debut, publisher Blitworks Games revealed that Dig or Die is digging (and dying) on over to PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X|S.

You can see more of what awaits in Dig or Die in the new Console Edition trailer below.

Dig or Die is another cautionary tale that warns of the risks inherent to crashing your spaceship on a hostile planet. While you attempt to rebuild your ship and escape, you’ll need to find a way to survive through crafting and, particularly after the sun sets, fending off hordes of vicious creatures.

There’s a lot of playing around with physics to be had here. Beyond just building structures, Dig or Die tasks you with making sure you actually do so thoughtfully. Build without care or consideration and your structures run the risk of collapsing, pushing your escape back even further. There are also water cycles—including threats of rain, underwater rivers, and other aquatic obstacles—that play into the integrity of your base and your basic survival. 

Down in the underground

Outside of the main areas, Dig or Die is full of procedurally-generated locales, so the layouts of everything from the surface to the depths of caves can change each time you play. There are also custom game modes that let you start out under a massive ocean or in a world made up of flying islands. Or simply skip all the exploration and play the stripped-down Base Defense mode for concentrated building and defending. 

You can dig and/or die when Dig or Die hits consoles on June 5, 2024.

item.title: PlayStation VR2 will soon work on PC with Sony’s new adapter, arriving this August
item.content:encoded:
https://www.destructoid.com/playstation-vr2-will-soon-work-on-pc-with-sonys-new-adapter-arriving-this-august/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=playstation-vr2-will-soon-work-on-pc-with-sonys-new-adapter-arriving-this-august

Sony is bringing its PlayStation VR2 headset to PC gamers, as an adapter for the headset is set to arrive for PC on August 7, 2024.

The PS VR2 headset was originally released for the PlayStation 5, but Sony is now expanding its functionality to make it possible for PC players to play VR games using the headset adapter.

The company has mentioned in the official PlayStation Blog that it built the PS VR2 from “the ground up specifically for PS5” which is why some features that are present on the PS5 will be missing on PC. These features include the absence of HDR, headset feedback, adaptive triggers, eye tracking, and haptic feedback (except rumbling).

However, features such as 4K resolution, 110-degree field of view, see-through view, finger touch detection, 3D Audio, and foveated rendering without eye tracking will be present for PC.

The PC adapter for PS VR2 will be sold for $59.99 in the US, and users will also need a DisplayPort 1.4 cable to use the headset for PC, sold separately.

How to set up PlayStation VR2 on PC

Players have to simply connect the PlayStation VR2 to their PC via the new PS VR2 PC adapter and a DisplayPort 1.4 cable. To play VR games on Steam, players have to download the SteamVR app from Steam, and they also have to download the PlayStation VR2 app for PC.

item.title: Destiny 2 published a list of known issues with The Final Shape, so read up
item.content:encoded:
https://www.destructoid.com/destiny-2-published-a-list-of-known-issues-with-the-final-shape-so-read-up/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=destiny-2-published-a-list-of-known-issues-with-the-final-shape-so-read-up

The release of Destiny 2: The Final Shape is an obviously monumental event for the classic Bungie franchise, but it was never going to be a flawless event. Bungie admits as much, too, as the company’s announced the full list of known problems to be aware of as we go.

Unless you’re eager to risk playing Destiny 2 wrong as you hop straight into The Final Shape, it’s good to be aware of these issues. Some of the listed problems are fairly inoffensive, while others straight-up warn you about one-and-done reward instances that you may well end up missing out on permanently, if you don’t know what you’re about. It’s not all bad, though: the list isn’t overly long, and it should be easy enough to stay on top of it.

Destiny 2: The Final Shape’s known issues

As per Bungie’s recently updated The Final Shape blog post, there’s about two dozen different issues to be mindful of, as The Final Shape begins to ramp up:

  • Players enjoying The Final Shape‘s campaign mode should avoid joining missions in-progress or swapping characters; failing to do so could lead to progress and/or reward loss.
  • PC players with 3D audio enabled will not get audio output from Destiny 2: The Final Shape. Bungie recommends switching the option off while playing the game.
  • Placeholder art is present during the ‘Leaving the Final Shape Campaign’ pop-up.
  • Casting the Prismatic Hunter’s Blink Dagger Super with the Stasis Grapple active nullifies all momentum and causes the character to fall down.
  • The Knock ‘Em Down’ Solar Hunter Aspect does not affect the number of Blade Barrage projectiles.
  • The Hunter Arc Staff Super description does not mention that certain attacks (i.e. the ground slam and the three-attack combo) apply Blind
  • The Deconstruct Perk description does not mention the new effect of refilling loaded magazine ammo from reserves.
  • Vestiges do not auto-convert into Memory items if there’s a Memory item present in your Inventory. Players need to obtain a new Vestige after using the Memory for Vestiges to convert into a new Memory.
  • Certain old seasonal items and currencies will not be automatically purged from player invenotires
  • Khvostov 7G-0X‘s Trait incorrectly claims that the ricochet rounds deal more damage.
  • If you had any tracked Triumphs that got Vaulted with the release of The Final Shape, you will not be able to untrack them.
  • If you do not open the final chest of the The Blooming Deep Lost Sector before the cutscene plays in The Final Shape‘s campaign, the rewards will be permanently lost.
  • Warlocks picking up a Stasis Shard with the Glacial Harvest Aspect active will not receive the healing effect.
  • The Berserker’s Bladefury Super does not properly apply the Woven Mail effect on allies when combined with the Into The Fray Aspect.

Nothing hugely game-breaking, then, but this is all stuff that we ought to be aware of. Hopefully, Bungie will be able to resolve all or almost all of these problems in the coming days and weeks, and in the interim, it’s at least good to know what we’re up against as The Final Shape finally rolls up.

Note, too, that Bungie does not intend to keep this list up-to-date after the release of Destiny 2: The Final Shape, so don’t expect it to meaningfully change or to be able to track future problems using it. Instead, it’s just a one-off snapshot of issues leading into the new campaign.
